-- | Contains information about an X.509 signing certificate.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   UploadSigningCertificate and ListSigningCertificates operations.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSigningCertificate</a> smart constructor.
data SigningCertificate
SigningCertificate' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Text -> Text -> Text -> StatusType -> SigningCertificate

-- | The date when the signing certificate was uploaded.
[$sel:uploadDate:SigningCertificate'] :: SigningCertificate -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | The name of the user the signing certificate is associated with.
[$sel:userName:SigningCertificate'] :: SigningCertificate -> Text

-- | The ID for the signing certificate.
[$sel:certificateId:SigningCertificate'] :: SigningCertificate -> Text

-- | The contents of the signing certificate.
[$sel:certificateBody:SigningCertificate'] :: SigningCertificate -> Text

-- | The status of the signing certificate. <tt>Active</tt> means that the
--   key is valid for API calls, while <tt>Inactive</tt> means it is not.
[$sel:status:SigningCertificate'] :: SigningCertificate -> StatusType

-- | Create a value of <a>SigningCertificate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:uploadDate:SigningCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>signingCertificate_uploadDate</a> - The date when the signing
--   certificate was uploaded.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:SigningCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>signingCertificate_userName</a> - The name of the user the signing
--   certificate is associated with.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certificateId:SigningCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>signingCertificate_certificateId</a> - The ID for the signing
--   certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certificateBody:SigningCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>signingCertificate_certificateBody</a> - The contents of the
--   signing certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:SigningCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>signingCertificate_status</a> - The status of the signing
--   certificate. <tt>Active</tt> means that the key is valid for API
--   calls, while <tt>Inactive</tt> means it is not.
newSigningCertificate :: Text -> Text -> Text -> StatusType -> SigningCertificate

-- | The date when the signing certificate was uploaded.
signingCertificate_uploadDate :: Lens' SigningCertificate (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The name of the user the signing certificate is associated with.
signingCertificate_userName :: Lens' SigningCertificate Text

-- | The ID for the signing certificate.
signingCertificate_certificateId :: Lens' SigningCertificate Text

-- | The contents of the signing certificate.
signingCertificate_certificateBody :: Lens' SigningCertificate Text

-- | The status of the signing certificate. <tt>Active</tt> means that the
--   key is valid for API calls, while <tt>Inactive</tt> means it is not.
signingCertificate_status :: Lens' SigningCertificate StatusType

-- | Contains the response to a successful SimulatePrincipalPolicy or
--   SimulateCustomPolicy request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSimulatePolicyResponse</a> smart constructor.
data SimulatePolicyResponse
SimulatePolicyResponse' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe [EvaluationResult] -> Maybe Text -> SimulatePolicyResponse

-- | A flag that indicates whether there are more items to return. If your
--   results were truncated, you can make a subsequent pagination request
--   using the <tt>Marker</tt> request parameter to retrieve more items.
--   Note that IAM might return fewer than the <tt>MaxItems</tt> number of
--   results even when there are more results available. We recommend that
--   you check <tt>IsTruncated</tt> after every call to ensure that you
--   receive all your results.
[$sel:isTruncated:SimulatePolicyResponse'] :: SimulatePolicyResponse -> Maybe Bool

-- | The results of the simulation.
[$sel:evaluationResults:SimulatePolicyResponse'] :: SimulatePolicyResponse -> Maybe [EvaluationResult]

-- | When <tt>IsTruncated</tt> is <tt>true</tt>, this element is present
--   and contains the value to use for the <tt>Marker</tt> parameter in a
--   subsequent pagination request.
[$sel:marker:SimulatePolicyResponse'] :: SimulatePolicyResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>SimulatePolicyResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:isTruncated:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_isTruncated</a> - A flag that indicates
--   whether there are more items to return. If your results were
--   truncated, you can make a subsequent pagination request using the
--   <tt>Marker</tt> request parameter to retrieve more items. Note that
--   IAM might return fewer than the <tt>MaxItems</tt> number of results
--   even when there are more results available. We recommend that you
--   check <tt>IsTruncated</tt> after every call to ensure that you receive
--   all your results.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationResults:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_evaluationResults</a> - The results of the
--   simulation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:marker:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_marker</a> - When <tt>IsTruncated</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>, this element is present and contains the value to use
--   for the <tt>Marker</tt> parameter in a subsequent pagination request.
newSimulatePolicyResponse :: SimulatePolicyResponse

-- | A flag that indicates whether there are more items to return. If your
--   results were truncated, you can make a subsequent pagination request
--   using the <tt>Marker</tt> request parameter to retrieve more items.
--   Note that IAM might return fewer than the <tt>MaxItems</tt> number of
--   results even when there are more results available. We recommend that
--   you check <tt>IsTruncated</tt> after every call to ensure that you
--   receive all your results.
simulatePolicyResponse_isTruncated :: Lens' SimulatePolicyResponse (Maybe Bool)

-- | The results of the simulation.
simulatePolicyResponse_evaluationResults :: Lens' SimulatePolicyResponse (Maybe [EvaluationResult])

-- | When <tt>IsTruncated</tt> is <tt>true</tt>, this element is present
--   and contains the value to use for the <tt>Marker</tt> parameter in a
--   subsequent pagination request.
simulatePolicyResponse_marker :: Lens' SimulatePolicyResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains a reference to a <tt>Statement</tt> element in a policy
--   document that determines the result of the simulation.
--   
--   This data type is used by the <tt>MatchedStatements</tt> member of the
--   <tt> EvaluationResult </tt> type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newStatement</a> smart constructor.
data Statement
Statement' :: Maybe Position -> Maybe PolicySourceType -> Maybe Position -> Maybe Text -> Statement

-- | The row and column of the beginning of the <tt>Statement</tt> in an
--   IAM policy.
[$sel:startPosition:Statement'] :: Statement -> Maybe Position

-- | The type of the policy.
[$sel:sourcePolicyType:Statement'] :: Statement -> Maybe PolicySourceType

-- | The row and column of the end of a <tt>Statement</tt> in an IAM
--   policy.
[$sel:endPosition:Statement'] :: Statement -> Maybe Position

-- | The identifier of the policy that was provided as an input.
[$sel:sourcePolicyId:Statement'] :: Statement -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Statement</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:startPosition:Statement'</a>, <a>statement_startPosition</a> -
--   The row and column of the beginning of the <tt>Statement</tt> in an
--   IAM policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourcePolicyType:Statement'</a>,
--   <a>statement_sourcePolicyType</a> - The type of the policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endPosition:Statement'</a>, <a>statement_endPosition</a> - The
--   row and column of the end of a <tt>Statement</tt> in an IAM policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourcePolicyId:Statement'</a>, <a>statement_sourcePolicyId</a>
--   - The identifier of the policy that was provided as an input.
newStatement :: Statement

-- | The row and column of the beginning of the <tt>Statement</tt> in an
--   IAM policy.
statement_startPosition :: Lens' Statement (Maybe Position)

-- | The type of the policy.
statement_sourcePolicyType :: Lens' Statement (Maybe PolicySourceType)

-- | The row and column of the end of a <tt>Statement</tt> in an IAM
--   policy.
statement_endPosition :: Lens' Statement (Maybe Position)

-- | The identifier of the policy that was provided as an input.
statement_sourcePolicyId :: Lens' Statement (Maybe Text)

-- | A structure that represents user-provided metadata that can be
--   associated with an IAM resource. For more information about tagging,
--   see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTag</a> smart constructor.
data Tag
Tag' :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | The key name that can be used to look up or retrieve the associated
--   value. For example, <tt>Department</tt> or <tt>Cost Center</tt> are
--   common choices.
[$sel:key:Tag'] :: Tag -> Text

-- | The value associated with this tag. For example, tags with a key name
--   of <tt>Department</tt> could have values such as <tt>Human
--   Resources</tt>, <tt>Accounting</tt>, and <tt>Support</tt>. Tags with a
--   key name of <tt>Cost Center</tt> might have values that consist of the
--   number associated with the different cost centers in your company.
--   Typically, many resources have tags with the same key name but with
--   different values.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.
[$sel:value:Tag'] :: Tag -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Tag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_key</a> - The key name that can be used
--   to look up or retrieve the associated value. For example,
--   <tt>Department</tt> or <tt>Cost Center</tt> are common choices.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_value</a> - The value associated with
--   this tag. For example, tags with a key name of <tt>Department</tt>
--   could have values such as <tt>Human Resources</tt>,
--   <tt>Accounting</tt>, and <tt>Support</tt>. Tags with a key name of
--   <tt>Cost Center</tt> might have values that consist of the number
--   associated with the different cost centers in your company. Typically,
--   many resources have tags with the same key name but with different
--   values.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.
newTag :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | The key name that can be used to look up or retrieve the associated
--   value. For example, <tt>Department</tt> or <tt>Cost Center</tt> are
--   common choices.
tag_key :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | The value associated with this tag. For example, tags with a key name
--   of <tt>Department</tt> could have values such as <tt>Human
--   Resources</tt>, <tt>Accounting</tt>, and <tt>Support</tt>. Tags with a
--   key name of <tt>Cost Center</tt> might have values that consist of the
--   number associated with the different cost centers in your company.
--   Typically, many resources have tags with the same key name but with
--   different values.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.
tag_value :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | Contains details about the most recent attempt to access an action
--   within the service.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetServiceLastAccessedDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTrackedActionLastAccessed</a> smart constructor.
data TrackedActionLastAccessed
TrackedActionLastAccessed' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> TrackedActionLastAccessed

-- | The name of the tracked action to which access was attempted. Tracked
--   actions are actions that report activity to IAM.
[$sel:actionName:TrackedActionLastAccessed'] :: TrackedActionLastAccessed -> Maybe Text

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an
--   authenticated entity most recently attempted to access the tracked
--   service. Amazon Web Services does not report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
[$sel:lastAccessedTime:TrackedActionLastAccessed'] :: TrackedActionLastAccessed -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | The Region from which the authenticated entity (user or role) last
--   attempted to access the tracked action. Amazon Web Services does not
--   report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
[$sel:lastAccessedRegion:TrackedActionLastAccessed'] :: TrackedActionLastAccessed -> Maybe Text
[$sel:lastAccessedEntity:TrackedActionLastAccessed'] :: TrackedActionLastAccessed -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>TrackedActionLastAccessed</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:actionName:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_actionName</a> - The name of the tracked
--   action to which access was attempted. Tracked actions are actions that
--   report activity to IAM.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAccessedTime:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedTime</a> - The date and time,
--   in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an authenticated entity most
--   recently attempted to access the tracked service. Amazon Web Services
--   does not report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAccessedRegion:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedRegion</a> - The Region from
--   which the authenticated entity (user or role) last attempted to access
--   the tracked action. Amazon Web Services does not report
--   unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAccessedEntity:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedEntity</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
newTrackedActionLastAccessed :: TrackedActionLastAccessed

-- | The name of the tracked action to which access was attempted. Tracked
--   actions are actions that report activity to IAM.
trackedActionLastAccessed_actionName :: Lens' TrackedActionLastAccessed (Maybe Text)

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an
--   authenticated entity most recently attempted to access the tracked
--   service. Amazon Web Services does not report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedTime :: Lens' TrackedActionLastAccessed (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The Region from which the authenticated entity (user or role) last
--   attempted to access the tracked action. Amazon Web Services does not
--   report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedRegion :: Lens' TrackedActionLastAccessed (Maybe Text)

-- | Undocumented member.
trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedEntity :: Lens' TrackedActionLastAccessed (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains information about an IAM user entity.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>CreateUser</li>
--   <li>GetUser</li>
--   <li>ListUsers</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUser</a> smart constructor.
data User
User' :: Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> ISO8601 -> User

-- | For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
[$sel:permissionsBoundary:User'] :: User -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the
--   user's password was last used to sign in to an Amazon Web Services
--   website. For a list of Amazon Web Services websites that capture a
--   user's last sign-in time, see the <a>Credential reports</a> topic in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>. If a password is used more than once in a
--   five-minute span, only the first use is returned in this field. If the
--   field is null (no value), then it indicates that they never signed in
--   with a password. This can be because:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user never had a password.</li>
--   <li>A password exists but has not been used since IAM started tracking
--   this information on October 20, 2014.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   A null value does not mean that the user <i>never</i> had a password.
--   Also, if the user does not currently have a password but had one in
--   the past, then this field contains the date and time the most recent
--   password was used.
--   
--   This value is returned only in the GetUser and ListUsers operations.
[$sel:passwordLastUsed:User'] :: User -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | A list of tags that are associated with the user. For more information
--   about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:tags:User'] :: User -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | The path to the user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM
--   identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
[$sel:path:User'] :: User -> Maybe Text

-- | The friendly name identifying the user.
[$sel:userName:User'] :: User -> Text

-- | The stable and unique string identifying the user. For more
--   information about IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:userId:User'] :: User -> Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more
--   information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see <a>IAM
--   Identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
[$sel:arn:User'] :: User -> Text

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user
--   was created.
[$sel:createDate:User'] :: User -> ISO8601

-- | Create a value of <a>User</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:User'</a>, <a>user_permissionsBoundary</a>
--   - For more information about permissions boundaries, see
--   <a>Permissions boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:passwordLastUsed:User'</a>, <a>user_passwordLastUsed</a> - The
--   date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user's
--   password was last used to sign in to an Amazon Web Services website.
--   For a list of Amazon Web Services websites that capture a user's last
--   sign-in time, see the <a>Credential reports</a> topic in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>. If a password is used more than once in a five-minute
--   span, only the first use is returned in this field. If the field is
--   null (no value), then it indicates that they never signed in with a
--   password. This can be because:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user never had a password.</li>
--   <li>A password exists but has not been used since IAM started tracking
--   this information on October 20, 2014.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   A null value does not mean that the user <i>never</i> had a password.
--   Also, if the user does not currently have a password but had one in
--   the past, then this field contains the date and time the most recent
--   password was used.
--   
--   This value is returned only in the GetUser and ListUsers operations.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:User'</a>, <a>user_tags</a> - A list of tags that are
--   associated with the user. For more information about tagging, see
--   <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:User'</a>, <a>user_path</a> - The path to the user. For
--   more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.
--   
--   The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:User'</a>, <a>user_userName</a> - The friendly name
--   identifying the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userId:User'</a>, <a>user_userId</a> - The stable and unique
--   string identifying the user. For more information about IDs, see
--   <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:User'</a>, <a>user_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and
--   how to use ARNs in policies, see <a>IAM Identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:User'</a>, <a>user_createDate</a> - The date and
--   time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user was created.
newUser :: Text -> Text -> Text -> UTCTime -> User

-- | For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
user_permissionsBoundary :: Lens' User (Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary)

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the
--   user's password was last used to sign in to an Amazon Web Services
--   website. For a list of Amazon Web Services websites that capture a
--   user's last sign-in time, see the <a>Credential reports</a> topic in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>. If a password is used more than once in a
--   five-minute span, only the first use is returned in this field. If the
--   field is null (no value), then it indicates that they never signed in
--   with a password. This can be because:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user never had a password.</li>
--   <li>A password exists but has not been used since IAM started tracking
--   this information on October 20, 2014.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   A null value does not mean that the user <i>never</i> had a password.
--   Also, if the user does not currently have a password but had one in
--   the past, then this field contains the date and time the most recent
--   password was used.
--   
--   This value is returned only in the GetUser and ListUsers operations.
user_passwordLastUsed :: Lens' User (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | A list of tags that are associated with the user. For more information
--   about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
user_tags :: Lens' User (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The path to the user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM
--   identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
user_path :: Lens' User (Maybe Text)

-- | The friendly name identifying the user.
user_userName :: Lens' User Text

-- | The stable and unique string identifying the user. For more
--   information about IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
user_userId :: Lens' User Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the user. For more
--   information about ARNs and how to use ARNs in policies, see <a>IAM
--   Identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
user_arn :: Lens' User Text

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user
--   was created.
user_createDate :: Lens' User UTCTime

-- | Contains information about an IAM user, including all the user's
--   policies and all the IAM groups the user is in.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUserDetail</a> smart constructor.
data UserDetail
UserDetail' :: Maybe [AttachedPolicy] -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [PolicyDetail] -> Maybe Text -> UserDetail

-- | A list of the managed policies attached to the user.
[$sel:attachedManagedPolicies:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe [AttachedPolicy]

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user
--   was created.
[$sel:createDate:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
[$sel:permissionsBoundary:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary
[$sel:arn:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of IAM groups that the user is in.
[$sel:groupList:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The stable and unique string identifying the user. For more
--   information about IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:userId:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of tags that are associated with the user. For more information
--   about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:tags:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | The friendly name identifying the user.
[$sel:userName:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe Text

-- | A list of the inline policies embedded in the user.
[$sel:userPolicyList:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe [PolicyDetail]

-- | The path to the user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM
--   identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
[$sel:path:UserDetail'] :: UserDetail -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UserDetail</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:attachedManagedPolicies:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_attachedManagedPolicies</a> - A list of the managed
--   policies attached to the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_createDate</a> - The
--   date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user was
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_permissionsBoundary</a> - The ARN of the policy used to
--   set the permissions boundary for the user.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_arn</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:groupList:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_groupList</a> - A
--   list of IAM groups that the user is in.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userId:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_userId</a> - The stable
--   and unique string identifying the user. For more information about
--   IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_tags</a> - A list of tags
--   that are associated with the user. For more information about tagging,
--   see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_userName</a> - The
--   friendly name identifying the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userPolicyList:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_userPolicyList</a> - A list of the inline policies
--   embedded in the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_path</a> - The path to the
--   user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newUserDetail :: UserDetail

-- | A list of the managed policies attached to the user.
userDetail_attachedManagedPolicies :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe [AttachedPolicy])

-- | The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user
--   was created.
userDetail_createDate :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
userDetail_permissionsBoundary :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary)

-- | Undocumented member.
userDetail_arn :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of IAM groups that the user is in.
userDetail_groupList :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe [Text])

-- | The stable and unique string identifying the user. For more
--   information about IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
userDetail_userId :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of tags that are associated with the user. For more information
--   about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
userDetail_tags :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The friendly name identifying the user.
userDetail_userName :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | A list of the inline policies embedded in the user.
userDetail_userPolicyList :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe [PolicyDetail])

-- | The path to the user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM
--   identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
userDetail_path :: Lens' UserDetail (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains information about a virtual MFA device.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newVirtualMFADevice</a> smart constructor.
data VirtualMFADevice
VirtualMFADevice' :: Maybe User -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64) -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64) -> Text -> VirtualMFADevice

-- | The IAM user associated with this virtual MFA device.
[$sel:user:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Maybe User

-- | The date and time on which the virtual MFA device was enabled.
[$sel:enableDate:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | A QR code PNG image that encodes
--   <tt>otpauth://totp/$virtualMFADeviceName@$AccountName?secret=$Base32String</tt>
--   where <tt>$virtualMFADeviceName</tt> is one of the create call
--   arguments. <tt>AccountName</tt> is the user name if set (otherwise,
--   the account ID otherwise), and <tt>Base32String</tt> is the seed in
--   base32 format. The <tt>Base32String</tt> value is base64-encoded.
[$sel:qRCodePNG:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64)

-- | A list of tags that are attached to the virtual MFA device. For more
--   information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
[$sel:tags:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | The base32 seed defined as specified in <a>RFC3548</a>. The
--   <tt>Base32StringSeed</tt> is base64-encoded.
[$sel:base32StringSeed:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64)

-- | The serial number associated with <tt>VirtualMFADevice</tt>.
[$sel:serialNumber:VirtualMFADevice'] :: VirtualMFADevice -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>VirtualMFADevice</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:VirtualMFADevice'</a>, <a>virtualMFADevice_user</a> - The
--   IAM user associated with this virtual MFA device.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableDate:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_enableDate</a> - The date and time on which the
--   virtual MFA device was enabled.
--   
--   <a>$sel:qRCodePNG:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_qRCodePNG</a> - A QR code PNG image that encodes
--   <tt>otpauth://totp/$virtualMFADeviceName@$AccountName?secret=$Base32String</tt>
--   where <tt>$virtualMFADeviceName</tt> is one of the create call
--   arguments. <tt>AccountName</tt> is the user name if set (otherwise,
--   the account ID otherwise), and <tt>Base32String</tt> is the seed in
--   base32 format. The <tt>Base32String</tt> value is base64-encoded.-- --
--   <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt> automatically encodes and decodes
--   Base64 data. -- The underlying isomorphism will encode to Base64
--   representation during -- serialisation, and decode from Base64
--   representation during deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts
--   and returns only raw unencoded data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:VirtualMFADevice'</a>, <a>virtualMFADevice_tags</a> - A
--   list of tags that are attached to the virtual MFA device. For more
--   information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:base32StringSeed:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_base32StringSeed</a> - The base32 seed defined as
--   specified in <a>RFC3548</a>. The <tt>Base32StringSeed</tt> is
--   base64-encoded.-- -- <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt> automatically
--   encodes and decodes Base64 data. -- The underlying isomorphism will
--   encode to Base64 representation during -- serialisation, and decode
--   from Base64 representation during deserialisation. -- This
--   <tt>Lens</tt> accepts and returns only raw unencoded data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serialNumber:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_serialNumber</a> - The serial number associated
--   with <tt>VirtualMFADevice</tt>.
newVirtualMFADevice :: Text -> VirtualMFADevice

-- | The IAM user associated with this virtual MFA device.
virtualMFADevice_user :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice (Maybe User)

-- | The date and time on which the virtual MFA device was enabled.
virtualMFADevice_enableDate :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | A QR code PNG image that encodes
--   <tt>otpauth://totp/$virtualMFADeviceName@$AccountName?secret=$Base32String</tt>
--   where <tt>$virtualMFADeviceName</tt> is one of the create call
--   arguments. <tt>AccountName</tt> is the user name if set (otherwise,
--   the account ID otherwise), and <tt>Base32String</tt> is the seed in
--   base32 format. The <tt>Base32String</tt> value is base64-encoded.-- --
--   <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt> automatically encodes and decodes
--   Base64 data. -- The underlying isomorphism will encode to Base64
--   representation during -- serialisation, and decode from Base64
--   representation during deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts
--   and returns only raw unencoded data.
virtualMFADevice_qRCodePNG :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice (Maybe ByteString)

-- | A list of tags that are attached to the virtual MFA device. For more
--   information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
virtualMFADevice_tags :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice (Maybe [Tag])

-- | The base32 seed defined as specified in <a>RFC3548</a>. The
--   <tt>Base32StringSeed</tt> is base64-encoded.-- -- <i>Note:</i> This
--   <tt>Lens</tt> automatically encodes and decodes Base64 data. -- The
--   underlying isomorphism will encode to Base64 representation during --
--   serialisation, and decode from Base64 representation during
--   deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts and returns only raw
--   unencoded data.
virtualMFADevice_base32StringSeed :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice (Maybe ByteString)

-- | The serial number associated with <tt>VirtualMFADevice</tt>.
virtualMFADevice_serialNumber :: Lens' VirtualMFADevice Text


-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM user. If a tag with the same key name
--   already exists, then that tag is overwritten with the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only
--   an IAM requesting user that has a specified tag attached. You can also
--   restrict access to only those resources that have a certain tag
--   attached. For examples of policies that show how to use tags to
--   control access, see <a>Control access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Cost allocation</b> - Use tags to help track which individuals
--   and teams are using which Amazon Web Services resources.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM identities</a>
--   in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagUser</a> smart constructor.
data TagUser
TagUser' :: Text -> [Tag] -> TagUser

-- | The name of the IAM user to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
[$sel:userName:TagUser'] :: TagUser -> Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM user. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value.
[$sel:tags:TagUser'] :: TagUser -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagUser</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:TagUser'</a>, <a>tagUser_userName</a> - The name of
--   the IAM user to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagUser'</a>, <a>tagUser_tags</a> - The list of tags that
--   you want to attach to the IAM user. Each tag consists of a key name
--   and an associated value.
newTagUser :: Text -> TagUser

-- | The name of the IAM user to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
tagUser_userName :: Lens' TagUser Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM user. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value.
tagUser_tags :: Lens' TagUser [Tag]

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagUserResponse</a> smart constructor.
data TagUserResponse
TagUserResponse' :: TagUserResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>TagUserResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newTagUserResponse :: TagUserResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUserResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUserResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUserResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUserResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUserResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.IAM.TagUser.TagUser


-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM server certificate. If a tag with the
--   same key name already exists, then that tag is overwritten with the
--   new value.
--   
--   For certificates in a Region supported by Certificate Manager (ACM),
--   we recommend that you don't use IAM server certificates. Instead, use
--   ACM to provision, manage, and deploy your server certificates. For
--   more information about IAM server certificates, <a>Working with server
--   certificates</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only a
--   server certificate that has a specified tag attached. For examples of
--   policies that show how to use tags to control access, see <a>Control
--   access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Cost allocation</b> - Use tags to help track which individuals
--   and teams are using which Amazon Web Services resources.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagServerCertificate

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagServerCertificate</a> smart constructor.
data TagServerCertificate
TagServerCertificate' :: Text -> [Tag] -> TagServerCertificate

-- | The name of the IAM server certificate to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
[$sel:serverCertificateName:TagServerCertificate'] :: TagServerCertificate -> Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM server
--   certificate. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.
[$sel:tags:TagServerCertificate'] :: TagServerCertificate -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagServerCertificate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverCertificateName:TagServerCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>tagServerCertificate_serverCertificateName</a> - The name of the
--   IAM server certificate to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagServerCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>tagServerCertificate_tags</a> - The list of tags that you want to
--   attach to the IAM server certificate. Each tag consists of a key name
--   and an associated value.
newTagServerCertificate :: Text -> TagServerCertificate

-- | The name of the IAM server certificate to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
tagServerCertificate_serverCertificateName :: Lens' TagServerCertificate Text

--   certificate. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.

-- | Adds one or more tags to a Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)
--   identity provider. For more information about these providers, see
--   <a>About SAML 2.0-based federation</a> . If a tag with the same key
--   name already exists, then that tag is overwritten with the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only a
--   SAML identity provider that has a specified tag attached. For examples
--   of policies that show how to use tags to control access, see
--   <a>Control access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagSAMLProvider

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagSAMLProvider</a> smart constructor.
data TagSAMLProvider
TagSAMLProvider' :: Text -> [Tag] -> TagSAMLProvider

-- | The ARN of the SAML identity provider in IAM to which you want to add
--   tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
[$sel:sAMLProviderArn:TagSAMLProvider'] :: TagSAMLProvider -> Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the SAML identity provider
--   in IAM. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.
[$sel:tags:TagSAMLProvider'] :: TagSAMLProvider -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagSAMLProvider</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sAMLProviderArn:TagSAMLProvider'</a>,
--   <a>tagSAMLProvider_sAMLProviderArn</a> - The ARN of the SAML identity
--   provider in IAM to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagSAMLProvider'</a>, <a>tagSAMLProvider_tags</a> - The
--   list of tags that you want to attach to the SAML identity provider in
--   IAM. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.
newTagSAMLProvider :: Text -> TagSAMLProvider

-- | The ARN of the SAML identity provider in IAM to which you want to add
--   tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
tagSAMLProvider_sAMLProviderArn :: Lens' TagSAMLProvider Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the SAML identity provider
--   in IAM. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.
tagSAMLProvider_tags :: Lens' TagSAMLProvider [Tag]

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagSAMLProviderResponse</a> smart constructor.
data TagSAMLProviderResponse
TagSAMLProviderResponse' :: TagSAMLProviderResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>TagSAMLProviderResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newTagSAMLProviderResponse :: TagSAMLProviderResponse

instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.IAM.TagSAMLProvider.TagSAMLProvider
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.IAM.TagSAMLProvider.TagSAMLProvider
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.IAM.TagSAMLProvider.TagSAMLProvider
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.IAM.TagSAMLProvider.TagSAMLProvider


-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM role. The role can be a regular role
--   or a service-linked role. If a tag with the same key name already
--   exists, then that tag is overwritten with the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only
--   an IAM role that has a specified tag attached. You can also restrict
--   access to only those resources that have a certain tag attached. For
--   examples of policies that show how to use tags to control access, see
--   <a>Control access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Cost allocation</b> - Use tags to help track which individuals
--   and teams are using which Amazon Web Services resources.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM identities</a>
--   in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagRole</a> smart constructor.
data TagRole
TagRole' :: Text -> [Tag] -> TagRole

-- | The name of the IAM role to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter accepts (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters that consist of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
[$sel:roleName:TagRole'] :: TagRole -> Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM role. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value.
[$sel:tags:TagRole'] :: TagRole -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagRole</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleName:TagRole'</a>, <a>tagRole_roleName</a> - The name of
--   the IAM role to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter accepts (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters that consist of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagRole'</a>, <a>tagRole_tags</a> - The list of tags that
--   you want to attach to the IAM role. Each tag consists of a key name
--   and an associated value.
newTagRole :: Text -> TagRole

-- | The name of the IAM role to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter accepts (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters that consist of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
tagRole_roleName :: Lens' TagRole Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM role. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value.
tagRole_tags :: Lens' TagRole [Tag]

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagRoleResponse</a> smart constructor.
data TagRoleResponse
TagRoleResponse' :: TagRoleResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>TagRoleResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newTagRoleResponse :: TagRoleResponse
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRoleResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRoleResponse
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRoleResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRoleResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRoleResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.IAM.TagRole.TagRole


-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM customer managed policy. If a tag with
--   the same key name already exists, then that tag is overwritten with
--   the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only
--   an IAM customer managed policy that has a specified tag attached. For
--   examples of policies that show how to use tags to control access, see
--   <a>Control access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagPolicy

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagPolicy</a> smart constructor.
data TagPolicy
TagPolicy' :: Text -> [Tag] -> TagPolicy

-- | The ARN of the IAM customer managed policy to which you want to add
--   tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
[$sel:policyArn:TagPolicy'] :: TagPolicy -> Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM customer managed
--   policy. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.
[$sel:tags:TagPolicy'] :: TagPolicy -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagPolicy</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyArn:TagPolicy'</a>, <a>tagPolicy_policyArn</a> - The ARN
--   of the IAM customer managed policy to which you want to add tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagPolicy'</a>, <a>tagPolicy_tags</a> - The list of tags
--   that you want to attach to the IAM customer managed policy. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value.
newTagPolicy :: Text -> TagPolicy

-- | The ARN of the IAM customer managed policy to which you want to add
--   tags.
--   
--   This parameter allows (through its <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of
--   characters consisting of upper and lowercase alphanumeric characters
--   with no spaces. You can also include any of the following characters:
--   _+=,.@-
tagPolicy_policyArn :: Lens' TagPolicy Text

-- | The list of tags that you want to attach to the IAM customer managed
--   policy. Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value.

-- | Adds one or more tags to an OpenID Connect (OIDC)-compatible identity
--   provider. For more information about these providers, see <a>About web
--   identity federation</a>. If a tag with the same key name already
--   exists, then that tag is overwritten with the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only
--   an OIDC provider that has a specified tag attached. For examples of
--   policies that show how to use tags to control access, see <a>Control
--   access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.IAM.TagOpenIDConnectProvider

-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM virtual multi-factor authentication
--   (MFA) device. If a tag with the same key name already exists, then
--   that tag is overwritten with the new value.
--   
--   A tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to
--   resources to aid in organization and search. For example, you could
--   search for all resources with the key name <i>Project</i> and the
--   value <i>MyImportantProject</i>. Or search for all resources with the
--   key name <i>Cost Center</i> and the value <i>41200</i>.</li>
--   <li><b>Access control</b> - Include tags in IAM user-based and
--   resource-based policies. You can use tags to restrict access to only
--   an IAM virtual MFA device that has a specified tag attached. For
--   examples of policies that show how to use tags to control access, see
--   <a>Control access using IAM tags</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed
--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>

--   to add tags. For virtual MFA devices, the serial number is the same as
--   the ARN.
--

-- | Adds one or more tags to an IAM instance profile. If a tag with the
--   same key name already exists, then that tag is overwritten with the
--   new value.
--   
--   Each tag consists of a key name and an associated value. By assigning
--   tags to your resources, you can do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Administrative grouping and discovery</b> - Attach tags to

--   maximum number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource
--   is not created. For more information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM
--   resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.</li>
--   <li>Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.</li>
--   </ul>

--   _+=,.@-
