--   can make a subsequent pagination request using the <tt>Marker</tt>
--   request parameter to retrieve more items. Note that IAM might return
--   fewer than the <tt>MaxItems</tt> number of results even when there are
--   more results available. We recommend that you check
--   <tt>IsTruncated</tt> after every call to ensure that you receive all
--   your results.
--   
--   <a>$sel:marker:ListRoles'</a>, <a>listRolesResponse_marker</a> - When
--   <tt>IsTruncated</tt> is <tt>true</tt>, this element is present and
--   contains the value to use for the <tt>Marker</tt> parameter in a
--   subsequent pagination request.

--   all IAM users in your account to use the Amazon Web Services
--   Management Console to change their own passwords. For more
--   information, see <a>Letting IAM users change their own passwords</a>
--   in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   If you do not specify a value for this parameter, then the operation
--   uses the default value of <tt>false</tt>. The result is that IAM users
--   in the account do not automatically have permissions to change their
--   own password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardExpiry:UpdateAccountPasswordPolicy'</a>,

--   from setting a new password after their password has expired. The IAM
--   user cannot be accessed until an administrator resets the password.
--   
--   If you do not specify a value for this parameter, then the operation
--   uses the default value of <tt>false</tt>. The result is that IAM users
--   can change their passwords after they expire and continue to sign in
--   as the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:requireSymbols:UpdateAccountPasswordPolicy'</a>,

--   non-alphanumeric characters:
--   
--   ! @ # $ % ^ &amp; * ( ) _ + - = [ ] { } | '
--   
--   If you do not specify a value for this parameter, then the operation
--   uses the default value of <tt>false</tt>. The result is that passwords

--

--   9).
--

--   uses the default value of <tt>false</tt>. The result is that passwords

--   that can be used to validate the SAML authentication response
--   (assertions) that are received from the IdP. You must generate the
--   metadata document using the identity management software that is used
--   as your organization's IdP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sAMLProviderArn:UpdateSAMLProvider'</a>,
--   <a>updateSAMLProvider_sAMLProviderArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the SAML provider to update.
--   
--   For more information about ARNs, see <a>Amazon Resource Names
--   (ARNs)</a> in the <i>Amazon Web Services General Reference</i>.
newUpdateSAMLProvider :: Text -> Text -> UpdateSAMLProvider

--   path prefix for filtering the results. For example:
--   <tt>/division_abc/subdivision_xyz/</tt>, which would get all user
--   names whose path starts with <tt>/division_abc/subdivision_xyz/</tt>.
--   
--   This parameter is optional. If it is not included, it defaults to a
--   slash (/), listing all user names. This parameter allows (through its
--   <a>regex pattern</a>) a string of characters consisting of either a
--   forward slash (/) by itself or a string that must begin and end with
--   forward slashes. In addition, it can contain any ASCII character from
--   the ! (<tt>\u0021</tt>) through the DEL character (<tt>\u007F</tt>),

--   lowercased letters.

--   only when paginating results to indicate the maximum number of items
--   you want in the response. If additional items exist beyond the maximum
--   you specify, the <tt>IsTruncated</tt> response element is
--   <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you do not include this parameter, the number of items defaults to
--   100. Note that IAM might return fewer results, even when there are
--   more results available. In that case, the <tt>IsTruncated</tt>
--   response element returns <tt>true</tt>, and <tt>Marker</tt> contains a
--   value to include in the subsequent call that tells the service where
--   to continue from.
--   
--   <a>$sel:marker:ListUsers'</a>, <a>listUsers_marker</a> - Use this
--   parameter only when paginating results and only after you receive a
--   response indicating that the results are truncated. Set it to the
--   value of the <tt>Marker</tt> element in the response that you received
--   to indicate where the next call should start.

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateRole</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxSessionDuration:UpdateRole'</a>,
--   <a>updateRole_maxSessionDuration</a> - The maximum session duration
--   (in seconds) that you want to set for the specified role. If you do
--   not specify a value for this setting, the default maximum of one hour
--   is applied. This setting can have a value from 1 hour to 12 hours.
--   
--   Anyone who assumes the role from the CLI or API can use the
--   <tt>DurationSeconds</tt> API parameter or the
--   <tt>duration-seconds</tt> CLI parameter to request a longer session.
--   The <tt>MaxSessionDuration</tt> setting determines the maximum
--   duration that can be requested using the <tt>DurationSeconds</tt>
--   parameter. If users don't specify a value for the
--   <tt>DurationSeconds</tt> parameter, their security credentials are
--   valid for one hour by default. This applies when you use the
--   <tt>AssumeRole*</tt> API operations or the <tt>assume-role*</tt> CLI
--   operations but does not apply when you use those operations to create
--   a console URL. For more information, see <a>Using IAM roles</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:UpdateRole'</a>, <a>updateRole_description</a> -
--   The new description that you want to apply to the specified role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleName:UpdateRole'</a>, <a>updateRole_roleName</a> - The
--   name of the role that you want to modify.
newUpdateRole :: Text -> UpdateRole

--   public key must be encoded in ssh-rsa format or PEM format. The
--   minimum bit-length of the public key is 2048 bits. For example, you
--   can generate a 2048-bit key, and the resulting PEM file is 1679 bytes
--   long.

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSimulateCustomPolicy</a> smart constructor.
data SimulateCustomPolicy
SimulateCustomPolicy' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [ContextEntry] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> [Text] -> [Text] -> SimulateCustomPolicy

-- | Create a value of <a>SimulateCustomPolicy</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceOwner:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_resourceOwner</a> - An ARN representing the
--   Amazon Web Services account ID that specifies the owner of any
--   simulated resource that does not identify its owner in the resource
--   ARN. Examples of resource ARNs include an S3 bucket or object. If
--   <tt>ResourceOwner</tt> is specified, it is also used as the account
--   owner of any <tt>ResourcePolicy</tt> included in the simulation. If
--   the <tt>ResourceOwner</tt> parameter is not specified, then the owner
--   of the resources and the resource policy defaults to the account of
--   the identity provided in <tt>CallerArn</tt>. This parameter is
--   required only if you specify a resource-based policy and account that
--   owns the resource is different from the account that owns the
--   simulated calling user <tt>CallerArn</tt>.
--   
--   The ARN for an account uses the following syntax:
--   <tt>arn:aws:iam::AWS-account-ID:root</tt>. For example, to represent
--   the account with the 112233445566 ID, use the following ARN:
--   <tt>arn:aws:iam::112233445566-ID:root</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contextEntries:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_contextEntries</a> - A list of context keys
--   and corresponding values for the simulation to use. Whenever a context
--   key is evaluated in one of the simulated IAM permissions policies, the
--   corresponding value is supplied.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourcePolicy:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_resourcePolicy</a> - A resource-based policy
--   to include in the simulation provided as a string. Each resource in
--   the simulation is treated as if it had this policy attached. You can
--   include only one resource-based policy in a simulation.
--   
--   The maximum length of the policy document that you can pass in this
--   operation, including whitespace, is listed below. To view the maximum
--   character counts of a managed policy with no whitespaces, see <a>IAM
--   and STS character quotas</a>.
--   
--   The <a>regex pattern</a> used to validate this parameter is a string
--   of characters consisting of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Any printable ASCII character ranging from the space character
--   (<tt>\u0020</tt>) through the end of the ASCII character range</li>
--   <li>The printable characters in the Basic Latin and Latin-1 Supplement
--   character set (through <tt>\u00FF</tt>)</li>
--   <li>The special characters tab (<tt>\u0009</tt>), line feed
--   (<tt>\u000A</tt>), and carriage return (<tt>\u000D</tt>)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundaryPolicyInputList:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_permissionsBoundaryPolicyInputList</a> - The
--   IAM permissions boundary policy to simulate. The permissions boundary
--   sets the maximum permissions that an IAM entity can have. You can
--   input only one permissions boundary when you pass a policy to this
--   operation. For more information about permissions boundaries, see
--   <a>Permissions boundaries for IAM entities</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>. The policy input is specified as a string that contains the
--   complete, valid JSON text of a permissions boundary policy.
--   
--   The maximum length of the policy document that you can pass in this
--   operation, including whitespace, is listed below. To view the maximum
--   character counts of a managed policy with no whitespaces, see <a>IAM
--   and STS character quotas</a>.
--   
--   The <a>regex pattern</a> used to validate this parameter is a string
--   of characters consisting of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Any printable ASCII character ranging from the space character
--   (<tt>\u0020</tt>) through the end of the ASCII character range</li>
--   <li>The printable characters in the Basic Latin and Latin-1 Supplement
--   character set (through <tt>\u00FF</tt>)</li>
--   <li>The special characters tab (<tt>\u0009</tt>), line feed
--   (<tt>\u000A</tt>), and carriage return (<tt>\u000D</tt>)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceArns:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_resourceArns</a> - A list of ARNs of Amazon
--   Web Services resources to include in the simulation. If this parameter
--   is not provided, then the value defaults to <tt>*</tt> (all
--   resources). Each API in the <tt>ActionNames</tt> parameter is
--   evaluated for each resource in this list. The simulation determines
--   the access result (allowed or denied) of each combination and reports
--   it in the response. You can simulate resources that don't exist in
--   your account.
--   
--   The simulation does not automatically retrieve policies for the
--   specified resources. If you want to include a resource policy in the
--   simulation, then you must include the policy as a string in the
--   <tt>ResourcePolicy</tt> parameter.
--   
--   If you include a <tt>ResourcePolicy</tt>, then it must be applicable
--   to all of the resources included in the simulation or you receive an
--   invalid input error.
--   
--   For more information about ARNs, see <a>Amazon Resource Names
--   (ARNs)</a> in the <i>Amazon Web Services General Reference</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceHandlingOption:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_resourceHandlingOption</a> - Specifies the
--   type of simulation to run. Different API operations that support
--   resource-based policies require different combinations of resources.
--   By specifying the type of simulation to run, you enable the policy
--   simulator to enforce the presence of the required resources to ensure
--   reliable simulation results. If your simulation does not match one of
--   the following scenarios, then you can omit this parameter. The
--   following list shows each of the supported scenario values and the
--   resources that you must define to run the simulation.
--   
--   Each of the EC2 scenarios requires that you specify instance, image,
--   and security-group resources. If your scenario includes an EBS volume,
--   then you must specify that volume as a resource. If the EC2 scenario
--   includes VPC, then you must supply the network-interface resource. If
--   it includes an IP subnet, then you must specify the subnet resource.
--   For more information on the EC2 scenario options, see <a>Supported
--   platforms</a> in the <i>Amazon EC2 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>EC2-Classic-InstanceStore</b>instance, image,
--   security-group</li>
--   <li><b>EC2-Classic-EBS</b>instance, image, security-group, volume</li>
--   <li><b>EC2-VPC-InstanceStore</b>instance, image, security-group,
--   network-interface</li>
--   <li><b>EC2-VPC-InstanceStore-Subnet</b>instance, image,
--   security-group, network-interface, subnet</li>
--   <li><b>EC2-VPC-EBS</b>instance, image, security-group,
--   network-interface, volume</li>
--   <li><b>EC2-VPC-EBS-Subnet</b>instance, image, security-group,
--   network-interface, subnet, volume</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:callerArn:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_callerArn</a> - The ARN of the IAM user that
--   you want to use as the simulated caller of the API operations.
--   <tt>CallerArn</tt> is required if you include a
--   <tt>ResourcePolicy</tt> so that the policy's <tt>Principal</tt>
--   element has a value to use in evaluating the policy.
--   
--   You can specify only the ARN of an IAM user. You cannot specify the
--   ARN of an assumed role, federated user, or a service principal.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxItems:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_maxItems</a> - Use this only when paginating
--   results to indicate the maximum number of items you want in the
--   response. If additional items exist beyond the maximum you specify,
--   the <tt>IsTruncated</tt> response element is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you do not include this parameter, the number of items defaults to
--   100. Note that IAM might return fewer results, even when there are
--   more results available. In that case, the <tt>IsTruncated</tt>
--   response element returns <tt>true</tt>, and <tt>Marker</tt> contains a
--   value to include in the subsequent call that tells the service where
--   to continue from.
--   
--   <a>$sel:marker:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_marker</a> - Use this parameter only when
--   paginating results and only after you receive a response indicating
--   that the results are truncated. Set it to the value of the
--   <tt>Marker</tt> element in the response that you received to indicate
--   where the next call should start.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyInputList:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_policyInputList</a> - A list of policy
--   documents to include in the simulation. Each document is specified as
--   a string containing the complete, valid JSON text of an IAM policy. Do
--   not include any resource-based policies in this parameter. Any
--   resource-based policy must be submitted with the
--   <tt>ResourcePolicy</tt> parameter. The policies cannot be "scope-down"
--   policies, such as you could include in a call to
--   <a>GetFederationToken</a> or one of the <a>AssumeRole</a> API
--   operations. In other words, do not use policies designed to restrict
--   what a user can do while using the temporary credentials.
--   
--   The maximum length of the policy document that you can pass in this
--   operation, including whitespace, is listed below. To view the maximum
--   character counts of a managed policy with no whitespaces, see <a>IAM
--   and STS character quotas</a>.
--   
--   The <a>regex pattern</a> used to validate this parameter is a string
--   of characters consisting of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Any printable ASCII character ranging from the space character
--   (<tt>\u0020</tt>) through the end of the ASCII character range</li>
--   <li>The printable characters in the Basic Latin and Latin-1 Supplement
--   character set (through <tt>\u00FF</tt>)</li>
--   <li>The special characters tab (<tt>\u0009</tt>), line feed
--   (<tt>\u000A</tt>), and carriage return (<tt>\u000D</tt>)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:actionNames:SimulateCustomPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>simulateCustomPolicy_actionNames</a> - A list of names of API
--   operations to evaluate in the simulation. Each operation is evaluated
--   against each resource. Each operation must include the service
--   identifier, such as <tt>iam:CreateUser</tt>. This operation does not
--   support using wildcards (*) in an action name.
newSimulateCustomPolicy :: SimulateCustomPolicy

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateOpenIDConnectProvider</a> smart constructor.
data CreateOpenIDConnectProvider
CreateOpenIDConnectProvider' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Tag] -> Text -> [Text] -> CreateOpenIDConnectProvider

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateOpenIDConnectProvider</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIDList:CreateOpenIDConnectProvider'</a>,
--   <a>createOpenIDConnectProvider_clientIDList</a> - Provides a list of
--   client IDs, also known as audiences. When a mobile or web app
--   registers with an OpenID Connect provider, they establish a value that
--   identifies the application. This is the value that's sent as the
--   <tt>client_id</tt> parameter on OAuth requests.
--   
--   You can register multiple client IDs with the same provider. For
--   example, you might have multiple applications that use the same OIDC
--   provider. You cannot register more than 100 client IDs with a single
--   IAM OIDC provider.
--   
--   There is no defined format for a client ID. The
--   <tt>CreateOpenIDConnectProviderRequest</tt> operation accepts client
--   IDs up to 255 characters long.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateOpenIDConnectProvider'</a>,
--   <a>createOpenIDConnectProvider_tags</a> - A list of tags that you want
--   to attach to the new IAM OpenID Connect (OIDC) provider. Each tag
--   consists of a key name and an associated value. For more information
--   about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   If any one of the tags is invalid or if you exceed the allowed maximum
--   number of tags, then the entire request fails and the resource is not
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:url:CreateOpenIDConnectProvider'</a>,
--   <a>createOpenIDConnectProvider_url</a> - The URL of the identity
--   provider. The URL must begin with <tt>https://</tt> and should
--   correspond to the <tt>iss</tt> claim in the provider's OpenID Connect
--   ID tokens. Per the OIDC standard, path components are allowed but
--   query parameters are not. Typically the URL consists of only a
--   hostname, like <tt>https://server.example.org</tt> or
--   <tt>https://example.com</tt>. The URL should not contain a port
--   number.
--   
--   You cannot register the same provider multiple times in a single
--   Amazon Web Services account. If you try to submit a URL that has
--   already been used for an OpenID Connect provider in the Amazon Web
--   Services account, you will get an error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:thumbprintList:CreateOpenIDConnectProvider'</a>,
--   <a>createOpenIDConnectProvider_thumbprintList</a> - A list of server
--   certificate thumbprints for the OpenID Connect (OIDC) identity
--   provider's server certificates. Typically this list includes only one
--   entry. However, IAM lets you have up to five thumbprints for an OIDC
--   provider. This lets you maintain multiple thumbprints if the identity
--   provider is rotating certificates.
--   
--   The server certificate thumbprint is the hex-encoded SHA-1 hash value
--   of the X.509 certificate used by the domain where the OpenID Connect
--   provider makes its keys available. It is always a 40-character string.
--   
--   You must provide at least one thumbprint when creating an IAM OIDC
--   provider. For example, assume that the OIDC provider is
--   <tt>server.example.com</tt> and the provider stores its keys at
--   https://keys.server.example.com/openid-connect. In that case, the
--   thumbprint string would be the hex-encoded SHA-1 hash value of the
--   certificate used by <tt>https://keys.server.example.com.</tt>
--   
--   For more information about obtaining the OIDC provider thumbprint, see
--   <a>Obtaining the thumbprint for an OpenID Connect provider</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newCreateOpenIDConnectProvider :: Text -> CreateOpenIDConnectProvider

--   request.
--

-- | The policy usage type that indicates whether the policy is used as a
--   permissions policy or as the permissions boundary for an entity.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.

-- | An object that contains details about when a principal in the reported
--   Organizations entity last attempted to access an Amazon Web Services
--   service. A principal can be an IAM user, an IAM role, or the Amazon
--   Web Services account root user within the reported Organizations
--   entity.
--   
--   This data type is a response element in the
--   GetOrganizationsAccessReport operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAccessDetail</a> smart constructor.
data AccessDetail
AccessDetail' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> AccessDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>AccessDetail</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:totalAuthenticatedEntities:AccessDetail'</a>,
--   <a>accessDetail_totalAuthenticatedEntities</a> - The number of
--   accounts with authenticated principals (root users, IAM users, and IAM
--   roles) that attempted to access the service in the reporting period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAuthenticatedTime:AccessDetail'</a>,
--   <a>accessDetail_lastAuthenticatedTime</a> - The date and time, in
--   <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an authenticated principal most
--   recently attempted to access the service. Amazon Web Services does not
--   report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no principals in the reported Organizations
--   entity attempted to access the service within the <a>reporting
--   period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:entityPath:AccessDetail'</a>, <a>accessDetail_entityPath</a> -
--   The path of the Organizations entity (root, organizational unit, or
--   account) from which an authenticated principal last attempted to
--   access the service. Amazon Web Services does not report
--   unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no principals (IAM users, IAM roles, or root
--   users) in the reported Organizations entity attempted to access the
--   service within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:AccessDetail'</a>, <a>accessDetail_region</a> - The
--   Region where the last service access attempt occurred.
--   
--   This field is null if no principals in the reported Organizations
--   entity attempted to access the service within the <a>reporting
--   period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:AccessDetail'</a>, <a>accessDetail_serviceName</a>
--   - The name of the service in which access was attempted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceNamespace:AccessDetail'</a>,
--   <a>accessDetail_serviceNamespace</a> - The namespace of the service in
--   which access was attempted.
--   
--   To learn the service namespace of a service, see <a>Actions,
--   resources, and condition keys for Amazon Web Services services</a> in
--   the <i>Service Authorization Reference</i>. Choose the name of the
--   service to view details for that service. In the first paragraph, find
--   the service prefix. For example, <tt>(service prefix: a4b)</tt>. For
--   more information about service namespaces, see <a>Amazon Web Services
--   service namespaces</a> in the <i>Amazon Web Services General
--   Reference</i>.
newAccessDetail :: Text -> Text -> AccessDetail

-- | Contains information about an Amazon Web Services access key.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the CreateAccessKey
--   and ListAccessKeys operations.
--   
--   The <tt>SecretAccessKey</tt> value is returned only in response to
--   CreateAccessKey. You can get a secret access key only when you first
--   create an access key; you cannot recover the secret access key later.
--   If you lose a secret access key, you must create a new access key.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAccessKeyInfo</a> smart constructor.
data AccessKeyInfo
AccessKeyInfo' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Text -> AccessKey -> StatusType -> Sensitive Text -> AccessKeyInfo

-- | Create a value of <a>AccessKeyInfo</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:AccessKeyInfo'</a>, <a>accessKeyInfo_createDate</a>
--   - The date when the access key was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:AccessKeyInfo'</a>, <a>accessKeyInfo_userName</a> -
--   The name of the IAM user that the access key is associated with.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessKeyId:AccessKeyInfo'</a>,
--   <a>accessKeyInfo_accessKeyId</a> - The ID for this access key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:AccessKeyInfo'</a>, <a>accessKeyInfo_status</a> - The
--   status of the access key. <tt>Active</tt> means that the key is valid
--   for API calls, while <tt>Inactive</tt> means it is not.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretAccessKey:AccessKeyInfo'</a>,
--   <a>accessKeyInfo_secretAccessKey</a> - The secret key used to sign
--   requests.
newAccessKeyInfo :: Text -> AccessKey -> StatusType -> Text -> AccessKeyInfo

-- | Contains information about the last time an Amazon Web Services access
--   key was used since IAM began tracking this information on April 22,
--   2015.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetAccessKeyLastUsed operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAccessKeyLastUsed</a> smart constructor.
data AccessKeyLastUsed
AccessKeyLastUsed' :: ISO8601 -> Text -> Text -> AccessKeyLastUsed

-- | Create a value of <a>AccessKeyLastUsed</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastUsedDate:AccessKeyLastUsed'</a>,
--   <a>accessKeyLastUsed_lastUsedDate</a> - The date and time, in <a>ISO
--   8601 date-time format</a>, when the access key was most recently used.
--   This field is null in the following situations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user does not have an access key.</li>
--   <li>An access key exists but has not been used since IAM began
--   tracking this information.</li>
--   <li>There is no sign-in data associated with the user.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:AccessKeyLastUsed'</a>,
--   <a>accessKeyLastUsed_serviceName</a> - The name of the Amazon Web
--   Services service with which this access key was most recently used.
--   The value of this field is "N/A" in the following situations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user does not have an access key.</li>
--   <li>An access key exists but has not been used since IAM started
--   tracking this information.</li>
--   <li>There is no sign-in data associated with the user.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:AccessKeyLastUsed'</a>, <a>accessKeyLastUsed_region</a>
--   - The Amazon Web Services Region where this access key was most
--   recently used. The value for this field is "N/A" in the following
--   situations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user does not have an access key.</li>
--   <li>An access key exists but has not been used since IAM began
--   tracking this information.</li>
--   <li>There is no sign-in data associated with the user.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about Amazon Web Services Regions, see <a>Regions
--   and endpoints</a> in the Amazon Web Services General Reference.
newAccessKeyLastUsed :: UTCTime -> Text -> Text -> AccessKeyLastUsed

--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.

-- | Contains information about a condition context key. It includes the
--   name of the key and specifies the value (or values, if the context key
--   supports multiple values) to use in the simulation. This information
--   is used when evaluating the <tt>Condition</tt> elements of the input
--   policies.
--   
--   This data type is used as an input parameter to SimulateCustomPolicy
--   and SimulatePrincipalPolicy.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newContextEntry</a> smart constructor.

--   <a>contextEntry_contextKeyValues</a> - The value (or values, if the
--   condition context key supports multiple values) to provide to the
--   simulation when the key is referenced by a <tt>Condition</tt> element
--   in an input policy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contextKeyName:ContextEntry'</a>,
--   <a>contextEntry_contextKeyName</a> - The full name of a condition
--   context key, including the service prefix. For example,
--   <tt>aws:SourceIp</tt> or <tt>s3:VersionId</tt>.
--

--   <a>contextEntry_contextKeyType</a> - The data type of the value (or
--   values) specified in the <tt>ContextKeyValues</tt> parameter.
newContextEntry :: ContextEntry

-- | Contains the results of a simulation.
--   
--   This data type is used by the return parameter of <tt>
--   SimulateCustomPolicy </tt> and <tt> SimulatePrincipalPolicy </tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEvaluationResult</a> smart constructor.
data EvaluationResult
EvaluationResult' :: Maybe (HashMap Text PolicyEvaluationDecisionType) -> Maybe OrganizationsDecisionDetail -> Maybe PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail -> Maybe [ResourceSpecificResult] -> Maybe [Statement] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Text -> PolicyEvaluationDecisionType -> EvaluationResult

-- | Create a value of <a>EvaluationResult</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalDecisionDetails:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_evalDecisionDetails</a> - Additional details about
--   the results of the cross-account evaluation decision. This parameter
--   is populated for only cross-account simulations. It contains a brief
--   summary of how each policy type contributes to the final evaluation
--   decision.
--   
--   If the simulation evaluates policies within the same account and
--   includes a resource ARN, then the parameter is present but the
--   response is empty. If the simulation evaluates policies within the
--   same account and specifies all resources (<tt>*</tt>), then the
--   parameter is not returned.
--   
--   When you make a cross-account request, Amazon Web Services evaluates
--   the request in the trusting account and the trusted account. The
--   request is allowed only if both evaluations return <tt>true</tt>. For
--   more information about how policies are evaluated, see <a>Evaluating
--   policies within a single account</a>.
--   
--   If an Organizations SCP included in the evaluation denies access, the
--   simulation ends. In this case, policy evaluation does not proceed any
--   further and this parameter is not returned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:organizationsDecisionDetail:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_organizationsDecisionDetail</a> - A structure that
--   details how Organizations and its service control policies affect the
--   results of the simulation. Only applies if the simulated user's
--   account is part of an organization.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_permissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail</a> - Contains
--   information about the effect that a permissions boundary has on a
--   policy simulation when the boundary is applied to an IAM entity.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceSpecificResults:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_resourceSpecificResults</a> - The individual
--   results of the simulation of the API operation specified in
--   EvalActionName on each resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:matchedStatements:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_matchedStatements</a> - A list of the statements
--   in the input policies that determine the result for this scenario.
--   Remember that even if multiple statements allow the operation on the
--   resource, if only one statement denies that operation, then the
--   explicit deny overrides any allow. In addition, the deny statement is
--   the only entry included in the result.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalResourceName:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_evalResourceName</a> - The ARN of the resource
--   that the indicated API operation was tested on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:missingContextValues:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_missingContextValues</a> - A list of context keys
--   that are required by the included input policies but that were not
--   provided by one of the input parameters. This list is used when the
--   resource in a simulation is "*", either explicitly, or when the
--   <tt>ResourceArns</tt> parameter blank. If you include a list of
--   resources, then any missing context values are instead included under
--   the <tt>ResourceSpecificResults</tt> section. To discover the context
--   keys used by a set of policies, you can call
--   GetContextKeysForCustomPolicy or GetContextKeysForPrincipalPolicy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalActionName:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_evalActionName</a> - The name of the API operation
--   tested on the indicated resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalDecision:EvaluationResult'</a>,
--   <a>evaluationResult_evalDecision</a> - The result of the simulation.
newEvaluationResult :: Text -> PolicyEvaluationDecisionType -> EvaluationResult

-- | Contains the response to a successful GetContextKeysForPrincipalPolicy
--   or GetContextKeysForCustomPolicy request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newGetContextKeysForPolicyResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse
GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse' :: Maybe [Text] -> GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:contextKeyNames:GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>getContextKeysForPolicyResponse_contextKeyNames</a> - The list of
--   context keys that are referenced in the input policies.
newGetContextKeysForPolicyResponse :: GetContextKeysForPolicyResponse

-- | Contains information about an IAM group entity.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>CreateGroup</li>

--   user password is valid.

--   present.

--   IAM user passwords must contain at least one uppercase character (A to
--   Z).

--   <a>passwordPolicy_allowUsersToChangePassword</a> - Specifies whether
--   IAM users are allowed to change their own password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardExpiry:PasswordPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>passwordPolicy_hardExpiry</a> - Specifies whether IAM users are
--   prevented from setting a new password after their password has
--   expired.
--

--   <a>passwordPolicy_requireSymbols</a> - Specifies whether IAM user
--   passwords must contain at least one of the following symbols:

--   ! @ # $ % ^ &amp; * ( ) _ + - = [ ] { } | '
--   
--   <a>$sel:requireNumbers:PasswordPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>passwordPolicy_requireNumbers</a> - Specifies whether IAM user
--   passwords must contain at least one numeric character (0 to 9).
newPasswordPolicy :: PasswordPolicy

-- | Contains information about the effect that a permissions boundary has
--   on a policy simulation when the boundary is applied to an IAM entity.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail</a> smart
--   constructor.
data PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail
PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail' :: Maybe Bool -> PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowedByPermissionsBoundary:PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail'</a>,
--   <a>permissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail_allowedByPermissionsBoundary</a>
--   - Specifies whether an action is allowed by a permissions boundary
--   that is applied to an IAM entity (user or role). A value of
--   <tt>true</tt> means that the permissions boundary does not deny the
--   action. This means that the policy includes an <tt>Allow</tt>
--   statement that matches the request. In this case, if an identity-based
--   policy also allows the action, the request is allowed. A value of
--   <tt>false</tt> means that either the requested action is not allowed
--   (implicitly denied) or that the action is explicitly denied by the
--   permissions boundary. In both of these cases, the action is not
--   allowed, regardless of the identity-based policy.
newPermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail :: PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail

--   For more information about IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newPolicy :: Policy

-- | Create a value of <a>PolicyGrantingServiceAccess</a> with all optional

--   
--   This field is null for managed policies. For more information about
--   these policy types, see <a>Managed policies and inline policies</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:entityType:PolicyGrantingServiceAccess'</a>,
--   <a>policyGrantingServiceAccess_entityType</a> - The type of entity
--   (user or role) that used the policy to access the service to which the
--   inline policy is attached.
--   
--   This field is null for managed policies. For more information about
--   these policy types, see <a>Managed policies and inline policies</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyArn:PolicyGrantingServiceAccess'</a>,
--   <a>policyGrantingServiceAccess_policyArn</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyName:PolicyGrantingServiceAccess'</a>,
--   <a>policyGrantingServiceAccess_policyName</a> - The policy name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policyType:PolicyGrantingServiceAccess'</a>,
--   <a>policyGrantingServiceAccess_policyType</a> - The policy type. For
--   more information about these policy types, see <a>Managed policies and
--   inline policies</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newPolicyGrantingServiceAccess :: Text -> PolicyType -> PolicyGrantingServiceAccess

-- | Contains information about a version of a managed policy.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   CreatePolicyVersion, GetPolicyVersion, ListPolicyVersions, and
--   GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operations.
--   
--   For more information about managed policies, refer to <a>Managed
--   policies and inline policies</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPolicyVersion</a> smart constructor.
data PolicyVersion
PolicyVersion' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> PolicyVersion

-- | Create a value of <a>PolicyVersion</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:PolicyVersion'</a>, <a>policyVersion_createDate</a>
--   - The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the
--   policy version was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:versionId:PolicyVersion'</a>, <a>policyVersion_versionId</a> -
--   The identifier for the policy version.
--   
--   Policy version identifiers always begin with <tt>v</tt> (always
--   lowercase). When a policy is created, the first policy version is
--   <tt>v1</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:document:PolicyVersion'</a>, <a>policyVersion_document</a> -
--   The policy document.
--   
--   The policy document is returned in the response to the
--   GetPolicyVersion and GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operations. It is
--   not returned in the response to the CreatePolicyVersion or
--   ListPolicyVersions operations.
--   
--   The policy document returned in this structure is URL-encoded
--   compliant with <a>RFC 3986</a>. You can use a URL decoding method to
--   convert the policy back to plain JSON text. For example, if you use
--   Java, you can use the <tt>decode</tt> method of the
--   <tt>java.net.URLDecoder</tt> utility class in the Java SDK. Other
--   languages and SDKs provide similar functionality.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isDefaultVersion:PolicyVersion'</a>,
--   <a>policyVersion_isDefaultVersion</a> - Specifies whether the policy
--   version is set as the policy's default version.
newPolicyVersion :: PolicyVersion

-- | Contains the row and column of a location of a <tt>Statement</tt>
--   element in a policy document.
--   
--   This data type is used as a member of the <tt> Statement </tt> type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPosition</a> smart constructor.
data Position
Position' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Position

-- | Create a value of <a>Position</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:column:Position'</a>, <a>position_column</a> - The column in
--   the line containing the specified position in the document.
--   
--   <a>$sel:line:Position'</a>, <a>position_line</a> - The line containing
--   the specified position in the document.
newPosition :: Position

-- | Contains the result of the simulation of a single API operation call
--   on a single resource.
--   
--   This data type is used by a member of the EvaluationResult data type.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newResourceSpecificResult</a> smart constructor.
data ResourceSpecificResult
ResourceSpecificResult' :: Maybe (HashMap Text PolicyEvaluationDecisionType) -> Maybe PermissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail -> Maybe [Statement] -> Maybe [Text] -> Text -> PolicyEvaluationDecisionType -> ResourceSpecificResult

-- | Create a value of <a>ResourceSpecificResult</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalDecisionDetails:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_evalDecisionDetails</a> - Additional details
--   about the results of the evaluation decision on a single resource.
--   This parameter is returned only for cross-account simulations. This
--   parameter explains how each policy type contributes to the
--   resource-specific evaluation decision.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_permissionsBoundaryDecisionDetail</a> -
--   Contains information about the effect that a permissions boundary has
--   on a policy simulation when that boundary is applied to an IAM entity.
--   
--   <a>$sel:matchedStatements:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_matchedStatements</a> - A list of the
--   statements in the input policies that determine the result for this
--   part of the simulation. Remember that even if multiple statements
--   allow the operation on the resource, if <i>any</i> statement denies
--   that operation, then the explicit deny overrides any allow. In
--   addition, the deny statement is the only entry included in the result.
--   
--   <a>$sel:missingContextValues:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_missingContextValues</a> - A list of context
--   keys that are required by the included input policies but that were
--   not provided by one of the input parameters. This list is used when a
--   list of ARNs is included in the <tt>ResourceArns</tt> parameter
--   instead of "*". If you do not specify individual resources, by setting
--   <tt>ResourceArns</tt> to "*" or by not including the
--   <tt>ResourceArns</tt> parameter, then any missing context values are
--   instead included under the <tt>EvaluationResults</tt> section. To
--   discover the context keys used by a set of policies, you can call
--   GetContextKeysForCustomPolicy or GetContextKeysForPrincipalPolicy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalResourceName:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_evalResourceName</a> - The name of the
--   simulated resource, in Amazon Resource Name (ARN) format.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evalResourceDecision:ResourceSpecificResult'</a>,
--   <a>resourceSpecificResult_evalResourceDecision</a> - The result of the
--   simulation of the simulated API operation on the resource specified in
--   <tt>EvalResourceName</tt>.
newResourceSpecificResult :: Text -> PolicyEvaluationDecisionType -> ResourceSpecificResult

-- | Contains information about an IAM role. This structure is returned as
--   a response element in several API operations that interact with roles.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRole</a> smart constructor.
data Role
Role' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe RoleLastUsed -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> ISO8601 -> Role

-- | Create a value of <a>Role</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:assumeRolePolicyDocument:Role'</a>,
--   <a>role_assumeRolePolicyDocument</a> - The policy that grants an
--   entity permission to assume the role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxSessionDuration:Role'</a>, <a>role_maxSessionDuration</a> -
--   The maximum session duration (in seconds) for the specified role.
--   Anyone who uses the CLI, or API to assume the role can specify the
--   duration using the optional <tt>DurationSeconds</tt> API parameter or
--   <tt>duration-seconds</tt> CLI parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleLastUsed:Role'</a>, <a>role_roleLastUsed</a> - Contains
--   information about the last time that an IAM role was used. This
--   includes the date and time and the Region in which the role was last
--   used. Activity is only reported for the trailing 400 days. This period
--   can be shorter if your Region began supporting these features within
--   the last year. The role might have been used more than 400 days ago.
--   For more information, see <a>Regions where data is tracked</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:Role'</a>, <a>role_permissionsBoundary</a>
--   - The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   role.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:Role'</a>, <a>role_tags</a> - A list of tags that are
--   attached to the role. For more information about tagging, see
--   <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:Role'</a>, <a>role_description</a> - A description
--   of the role that you provide.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:Role'</a>, <a>role_path</a> - The path to the role. For
--   more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleName:Role'</a>, <a>role_roleName</a> - The friendly name
--   that identifies the role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleId:Role'</a>, <a>role_roleId</a> - The stable and unique
--   string identifying the role. For more information about IDs, see
--   <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:Role'</a>, <a>role_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) specifying the role. For more information about ARNs and how to
--   use them in policies, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i> guide.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:Role'</a>, <a>role_createDate</a> - The date and
--   time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the role was created.
newRole :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> UTCTime -> Role

-- | Contains information about an IAM role, including all of the role's
--   policies.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRoleDetail</a> smart constructor.
data RoleDetail
RoleDetail' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe RoleLastUsed -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [AttachedPolicy] -> Maybe [PolicyDetail] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe [InstanceProfile] -> Maybe Text -> RoleDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>RoleDetail</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:assumeRolePolicyDocument:RoleDetail'</a>,
--   <a>roleDetail_assumeRolePolicyDocument</a> - The trust policy that
--   grants permission to assume the role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleLastUsed:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_roleLastUsed</a> -
--   Contains information about the last time that an IAM role was used.
--   This includes the date and time and the Region in which the role was
--   last used. Activity is only reported for the trailing 400 days. This
--   period can be shorter if your Region began supporting these features
--   within the last year. The role might have been used more than 400 days
--   ago. For more information, see <a>Regions where data is tracked</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleId:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_roleId</a> - The stable
--   and unique string identifying the role. For more information about
--   IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:attachedManagedPolicies:RoleDetail'</a>,
--   <a>roleDetail_attachedManagedPolicies</a> - A list of managed policies
--   attached to the role. These policies are the role's access
--   (permissions) policies.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rolePolicyList:RoleDetail'</a>,
--   <a>roleDetail_rolePolicyList</a> - A list of inline policies embedded
--   in the role. These policies are the role's access (permissions)
--   policies.
--   
--   <a>$sel:roleName:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_roleName</a> - The
--   friendly name that identifies the role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_createDate</a> - The
--   date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the role was
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:RoleDetail'</a>,
--   <a>roleDetail_permissionsBoundary</a> - The ARN of the policy used to
--   set the permissions boundary for the role.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_arn</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_tags</a> - A list of tags
--   that are attached to the role. For more information about tagging, see
--   <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceProfileList:RoleDetail'</a>,
--   <a>roleDetail_instanceProfileList</a> - A list of instance profiles
--   that contain this role.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:RoleDetail'</a>, <a>roleDetail_path</a> - The path to the
--   role. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newRoleDetail :: RoleDetail

-- | Contains information about the last time that an IAM role was used.
--   This includes the date and time and the Region in which the role was
--   last used. Activity is only reported for the trailing 400 days. This
--   period can be shorter if your Region began supporting these features
--   within the last year. The role might have been used more than 400 days
--   ago. For more information, see <a>Regions where data is tracked</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   This data type is returned as a response element in the GetRole and
--   GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operations.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRoleLastUsed</a> smart constructor.
data RoleLastUsed
RoleLastUsed' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> RoleLastUsed

-- | Create a value of <a>RoleLastUsed</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastUsedDate:RoleLastUsed'</a>,
--   <a>roleLastUsed_lastUsedDate</a> - The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601
--   date-time format</a> that the role was last used.
--   
--   This field is null if the role has not been used within the IAM
--   tracking period. For more information about the tracking period, see
--   <a>Regions where data is tracked</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:region:RoleLastUsed'</a>, <a>roleLastUsed_region</a> - The
--   name of the Amazon Web Services Region in which the role was last
--   used.
newRoleLastUsed :: RoleLastUsed

-- | An object that contains details about how a service-linked role is

newRoleUsageType :: RoleUsageType

-- | Contains information about an SSH public key.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the GetSSHPublicKey
--   and UploadSSHPublicKey operations.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSSHPublicKey</a> smart constructor.
data SSHPublicKey
SSHPublicKey' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> StatusType -> SSHPublicKey

-- | Create a value of <a>SSHPublicKey</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:uploadDate:SSHPublicKey'</a>, <a>sSHPublicKey_uploadDate</a> -
--   The date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the SSH
--   public key was uploaded.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:SSHPublicKey'</a>, <a>sSHPublicKey_userName</a> - The
--   name of the IAM user associated with the SSH public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSHPublicKeyId:SSHPublicKey'</a>,
--   <a>sSHPublicKey_sSHPublicKeyId</a> - The unique identifier for the SSH
--   public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fingerprint:SSHPublicKey'</a>, <a>sSHPublicKey_fingerprint</a>
--   - The MD5 message digest of the SSH public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSHPublicKeyBody:SSHPublicKey'</a>,
--   <a>sSHPublicKey_sSHPublicKeyBody</a> - The SSH public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:SSHPublicKey'</a>, <a>sSHPublicKey_status</a> - The
--   status of the SSH public key. <tt>Active</tt> means that the key can
--   be used for authentication with an CodeCommit repository.
--   <tt>Inactive</tt> means that the key cannot be used.
newSSHPublicKey :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> StatusType -> SSHPublicKey

-- | Contains information about an SSH public key, without the key's body
--   or fingerprint.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the ListSSHPublicKeys
--   operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSSHPublicKeyMetadata</a> smart constructor.
data SSHPublicKeyMetadata
SSHPublicKeyMetadata' :: Text -> Text -> StatusType -> ISO8601 -> SSHPublicKeyMetadata

-- | Create a value of <a>SSHPublicKeyMetadata</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--

--

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   associated with the SSH public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSHPublicKeyId:SSHPublicKeyMetadata'</a>,
--   <a>sSHPublicKeyMetadata_sSHPublicKeyId</a> - The unique identifier for
--   the SSH public key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:SSHPublicKeyMetadata'</a>,
--   <a>sSHPublicKeyMetadata_status</a> - The status of the SSH public key.
--   <tt>Active</tt> means that the key can be used for authentication with
--   an CodeCommit repository. <tt>Inactive</tt> means that the key cannot
--   be used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:uploadDate:SSHPublicKeyMetadata'</a>,
--   <a>sSHPublicKeyMetadata_uploadDate</a> - The date and time, in <a>ISO
--   8601 date-time format</a>, when the SSH public key was uploaded.
newSSHPublicKeyMetadata :: Text -> Text -> StatusType -> UTCTime -> SSHPublicKeyMetadata

-- | Contains information about a server certificate.

data ServerCertificate

-- | Create a value of <a>ServerCertificate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:ServerCertificate'</a>, <a>serverCertificate_tags</a> - A
--   list of tags that are attached to the server certificate. For more
--   information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certificateChain:ServerCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>serverCertificate_certificateChain</a> - The contents of the public
--   key certificate chain.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverCertificateMetadata:ServerCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>serverCertificate_serverCertificateMetadata</a> - The meta
--   information of the server certificate, such as its name, path, ID, and
--   ARN.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certificateBody:ServerCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>serverCertificate_certificateBody</a> - The contents of the public
--   key certificate.
newServerCertificate :: ServerCertificateMetadata -> Text -> ServerCertificate

newServerCertificateMetadata :: Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> ServerCertificateMetadata

-- | Contains details about the most recent attempt to access the service.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetServiceLastAccessedDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newServiceLastAccessed</a> smart constructor.
data ServiceLastAccessed
ServiceLastAccessed' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [TrackedActionLastAccessed] -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Text -> Text -> ServiceLastAccessed

-- | Create a value of <a>ServiceLastAccessed</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:totalAuthenticatedEntities:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_totalAuthenticatedEntities</a> - The total
--   number of authenticated principals (root user, IAM users, or IAM
--   roles) that have attempted to access the service.
--   
--   This field is null if no principals attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAuthenticatedRegion:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_lastAuthenticatedRegion</a> - The Region from
--   which the authenticated entity (user or role) last attempted to access
--   the service. Amazon Web Services does not report unauthenticated
--   requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAuthenticatedEntity:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_lastAuthenticatedEntity</a> - The ARN of the
--   authenticated entity (user or role) that last attempted to access the
--   service. Amazon Web Services does not report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trackedActionsLastAccessed:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_trackedActionsLastAccessed</a> - An object that
--   contains details about the most recent attempt to access a tracked
--   action within the service.
--   
--   This field is null if there no tracked actions or if the principal did
--   not use the tracked actions within the <a>reporting period</a>. This
--   field is also null if the report was generated at the service level
--   and not the action level. For more information, see the
--   <tt>Granularity</tt> field in GenerateServiceLastAccessedDetails.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAuthenticated:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_lastAuthenticated</a> - The date and time, in
--   <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an authenticated entity most
--   recently attempted to access the service. Amazon Web Services does not
--   report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_serviceName</a> - The name of the service in
--   which access was attempted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceNamespace:ServiceLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>serviceLastAccessed_serviceNamespace</a> - The namespace of the
--   service in which access was attempted.
--   
--   To learn the service namespace of a service, see <a>Actions,
--   resources, and condition keys for Amazon Web Services services</a> in
--   the <i>Service Authorization Reference</i>. Choose the name of the
--   service to view details for that service. In the first paragraph, find
--   the service prefix. For example, <tt>(service prefix: a4b)</tt>. For
--   more information about service namespaces, see <a>Amazon Web Services
--   Service Namespaces</a> in the <i>Amazon Web Services General
--   Reference</i>.
newServiceLastAccessed :: Text -> Text -> ServiceLastAccessed

data ServiceSpecificCredential

-- | Create a value of <a>ServiceSpecificCredential</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the service-specific credential
--   were created.

--   <a>$sel:serviceName:ServiceSpecificCredential'</a>,
--   <a>serviceSpecificCredential_serviceName</a> - The name of the service
--   associated with the service-specific credential.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceUserName:ServiceSpecificCredential'</a>,
--   <a>serviceSpecificCredential_serviceUserName</a> - The generated user
--   name for the service-specific credential. This value is generated by
--   combining the IAM user's name combined with the ID number of the
--   Amazon Web Services account, as in <tt>jane-at-123456789012</tt>, for
--   example. This value cannot be configured by the user.

--   associated with the service-specific credential.
--

--   <a>serviceSpecificCredential_status</a> - The status of the
--   service-specific credential. <tt>Active</tt> means that the key is
--   valid for API calls, while <tt>Inactive</tt> means it is not.

-- | Contains the response to a successful SimulatePrincipalPolicy or
--   SimulateCustomPolicy request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSimulatePolicyResponse</a> smart constructor.
data SimulatePolicyResponse
SimulatePolicyResponse' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe [EvaluationResult] -> Maybe Text -> SimulatePolicyResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>SimulatePolicyResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:isTruncated:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_isTruncated</a> - A flag that indicates
--   whether there are more items to return. If your results were
--   truncated, you can make a subsequent pagination request using the
--   <tt>Marker</tt> request parameter to retrieve more items. Note that
--   IAM might return fewer than the <tt>MaxItems</tt> number of results
--   even when there are more results available. We recommend that you
--   check <tt>IsTruncated</tt> after every call to ensure that you receive
--   all your results.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationResults:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_evaluationResults</a> - The results of the
--   simulation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:marker:SimulatePolicyResponse'</a>,
--   <a>simulatePolicyResponse_marker</a> - When <tt>IsTruncated</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>, this element is present and contains the value to use
--   for the <tt>Marker</tt> parameter in a subsequent pagination request.
newSimulatePolicyResponse :: SimulatePolicyResponse

-- | Contains a reference to a <tt>Statement</tt> element in a policy

--   
--   <a>$sel:sourcePolicyId:Statement'</a>, <a>statement_sourcePolicyId</a>
--   - The identifier of the policy that was provided as an input.
newStatement :: Statement

-- | A structure that represents user-provided metadata that can be
--   associated with an IAM resource. For more information about tagging,
--   see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTag</a> smart constructor.
data Tag
Tag' :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | Create a value of <a>Tag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_key</a> - The key name that can be used
--   to look up or retrieve the associated value. For example,
--   <tt>Department</tt> or <tt>Cost Center</tt> are common choices.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_value</a> - The value associated with
--   this tag. For example, tags with a key name of <tt>Department</tt>
--   could have values such as <tt>Human Resources</tt>,
--   <tt>Accounting</tt>, and <tt>Support</tt>. Tags with a key name of
--   <tt>Cost Center</tt> might have values that consist of the number
--   associated with the different cost centers in your company. Typically,
--   many resources have tags with the same key name but with different
--   values.
--   
--   Amazon Web Services always interprets the tag <tt>Value</tt> as a
--   single string. If you need to store an array, you can store
--   comma-separated values in the string. However, you must interpret the
--   value in your code.
newTag :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | Contains details about the most recent attempt to access an action
--   within the service.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetServiceLastAccessedDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTrackedActionLastAccessed</a> smart constructor.
data TrackedActionLastAccessed

-- | Create a value of <a>TrackedActionLastAccessed</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_actionName</a> - The name of the tracked
--   action to which access was attempted. Tracked actions are actions that
--   report activity to IAM.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAccessedTime:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedTime</a> - The date and time,
--   in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when an authenticated entity most
--   recently attempted to access the tracked service. Amazon Web Services
--   does not report unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastAccessedRegion:TrackedActionLastAccessed'</a>,
--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedRegion</a> - The Region from
--   which the authenticated entity (user or role) last attempted to access
--   the tracked action. Amazon Web Services does not report
--   unauthenticated requests.
--   
--   This field is null if no IAM entities attempted to access the service
--   within the <a>reporting period</a>.

--   <a>trackedActionLastAccessed_lastAccessedEntity</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
newTrackedActionLastAccessed :: TrackedActionLastAccessed

-- | Contains information about an IAM user entity.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>CreateUser</li>
--   <li>GetUser</li>
--   <li>ListUsers</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUser</a> smart constructor.
data User
User' :: Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> Text -> ISO8601 -> User

-- | Create a value of <a>User</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:User'</a>, <a>user_permissionsBoundary</a>
--   - For more information about permissions boundaries, see
--   <a>Permissions boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:passwordLastUsed:User'</a>, <a>user_passwordLastUsed</a> - The
--   date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user's
--   password was last used to sign in to an Amazon Web Services website.
--   For a list of Amazon Web Services websites that capture a user's last
--   sign-in time, see the <a>Credential reports</a> topic in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>. If a password is used more than once in a five-minute
--   span, only the first use is returned in this field. If the field is
--   null (no value), then it indicates that they never signed in with a
--   password. This can be because:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The user never had a password.</li>
--   <li>A password exists but has not been used since IAM started tracking
--   this information on October 20, 2014.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   A null value does not mean that the user <i>never</i> had a password.
--   Also, if the user does not currently have a password but had one in
--   the past, then this field contains the date and time the most recent
--   password was used.
--   
--   This value is returned only in the GetUser and ListUsers operations.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:User'</a>, <a>user_tags</a> - A list of tags that are
--   associated with the user. For more information about tagging, see
--   <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:User'</a>, <a>user_path</a> - The path to the user. For
--   more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.
--   
--   The ARN of the policy used to set the permissions boundary for the
--   user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:User'</a>, <a>user_userName</a> - The friendly name
--   identifying the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userId:User'</a>, <a>user_userId</a> - The stable and unique
--   string identifying the user. For more information about IDs, see
--   <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:User'</a>, <a>user_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) that identifies the user. For more information about ARNs and
--   how to use ARNs in policies, see <a>IAM Identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM
--   User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:User'</a>, <a>user_createDate</a> - The date and
--   time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user was created.
newUser :: Text -> Text -> Text -> UTCTime -> User

-- | Contains information about an IAM user, including all the user's
--   policies and all the IAM groups the user is in.
--   
--   This data type is used as a response element in the
--   GetAccountAuthorizationDetails operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newUserDetail</a> smart constructor.
data UserDetail
UserDetail' :: Maybe [AttachedPolicy] -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe AttachedPermissionsBoundary -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [PolicyDetail] -> Maybe Text -> UserDetail

-- | Create a value of <a>UserDetail</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:attachedManagedPolicies:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_attachedManagedPolicies</a> - A list of the managed
--   policies attached to the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createDate:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_createDate</a> - The
--   date and time, in <a>ISO 8601 date-time format</a>, when the user was
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:permissionsBoundary:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_permissionsBoundary</a> - The ARN of the policy used to
--   set the permissions boundary for the user.
--   
--   For more information about permissions boundaries, see <a>Permissions
--   boundaries for IAM identities</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_arn</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:groupList:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_groupList</a> - A
--   list of IAM groups that the user is in.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userId:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_userId</a> - The stable
--   and unique string identifying the user. For more information about
--   IDs, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_tags</a> - A list of tags
--   that are associated with the user. For more information about tagging,
--   see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userName:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_userName</a> - The
--   friendly name identifying the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:userPolicyList:UserDetail'</a>,
--   <a>userDetail_userPolicyList</a> - A list of the inline policies
--   embedded in the user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:path:UserDetail'</a>, <a>userDetail_path</a> - The path to the
--   user. For more information about paths, see <a>IAM identifiers</a> in
--   the <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
newUserDetail :: UserDetail

-- | Contains information about a virtual MFA device.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newVirtualMFADevice</a> smart constructor.
data VirtualMFADevice
VirtualMFADevice' :: Maybe User -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64) -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe (Sensitive Base64) -> Text -> VirtualMFADevice

-- | Create a value of <a>VirtualMFADevice</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:user:VirtualMFADevice'</a>, <a>virtualMFADevice_user</a> - The
--   IAM user associated with this virtual MFA device.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableDate:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_enableDate</a> - The date and time on which the
--   virtual MFA device was enabled.
--   
--   <a>$sel:qRCodePNG:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_qRCodePNG</a> - A QR code PNG image that encodes
--   <tt>otpauth://totp/$virtualMFADeviceName@$AccountName?secret=$Base32String</tt>
--   where <tt>$virtualMFADeviceName</tt> is one of the create call
--   arguments. <tt>AccountName</tt> is the user name if set (otherwise,
--   the account ID otherwise), and <tt>Base32String</tt> is the seed in
--   base32 format. The <tt>Base32String</tt> value is base64-encoded.-- --
--   <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt> automatically encodes and decodes
--   Base64 data. -- The underlying isomorphism will encode to Base64
--   representation during -- serialisation, and decode from Base64
--   representation during deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts
--   and returns only raw unencoded data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:VirtualMFADevice'</a>, <a>virtualMFADevice_tags</a> - A
--   list of tags that are attached to the virtual MFA device. For more
--   information about tagging, see <a>Tagging IAM resources</a> in the
--   <i>IAM User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:base32StringSeed:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_base32StringSeed</a> - The base32 seed defined as
--   specified in <a>RFC3548</a>. The <tt>Base32StringSeed</tt> is
--   base64-encoded.-- -- <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt> automatically
--   encodes and decodes Base64 data. -- The underlying isomorphism will
--   encode to Base64 representation during -- serialisation, and decode
--   from Base64 representation during deserialisation. -- This
--   <tt>Lens</tt> accepts and returns only raw unencoded data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serialNumber:VirtualMFADevice'</a>,
--   <a>virtualMFADevice_serialNumber</a> - The serial number associated
--   with <tt>VirtualMFADevice</tt>.
newVirtualMFADevice :: Text -> VirtualMFADevice
